abstractText: Lithium (Li) metal is considered as an ideal negative electrode material for next-generation secondary batteries; however, the hideous dendrite growth and parasitic reactions hinder the practical applications of Li metal batteries. Herein, a hybrid polymer film composed of polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) and polyacrylic acid (PAA) is adopted as an artificial protective layer to inhibit the dendritic formation and side reactions in Li metal anodes. PVA with large quantities of polar functional groups can induce even distribution of Li ions (Li). Alternatively, PAA can in situ react with Li metal to form highly elastic and ionic conducting lithium polyacrylic acid (LiPAA), thereby enabling tight contact and flexible self-adaption with Li metal anodes. Therefore, such a rationally designed functional composite layer, with good binding ability and relatively high Li conductivity, as well as excellent capability of homogenizing Li flow, accordingly enables Li metal anodes to reveal dendrite-free plating/stripping behaviours and minimum volume variation. As a result, the PVA–PAA modified Li metal anode delivered stable cycling for 700 and 250 h, respectively, at current densities of 1 and 3 mA cm−2 under an areal capacity of 1 mA h cm−2, in a carbonate ester-based electrolyte without any additive, exhibiting boosted cycling and rate performances. The Li anode with a functional PVA–PAA hybrid interlayer can maintain the dense and smooth texture without dendrite formation after long cycles. The full cell of LijLiFeO4 with our modified Li anode and a cathode with a high areal capacity of 2.45 mA h cm−2 delivers, change to achieved a long-term lifespan of 180 cycles at 1.0 C, with a capacity retention of 96.7%. This work demonstrates a simple and effective strategy of designing multi-functional artificial protective layers, targeting dendrite-free Li anodes.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Owing to the ultra-high specic capacity (3860 mA h cm−2) and low reduction potential (−3.04 V vs. the standard hydrogen electrode (SHE)), lithium (Li) metal has been recognized as a promising candidate for anodes of rechargeable Li metal batteries (LMBs).1–4 Nevertheless, the detrimental dendrite growth and serious side reactions during cycling are two main obstacles in the way of commercial implementation of LMBs.3,5 It is widely known that the solid interphase electrolyte (SEI) layer formed on the bare Li metal anode is fragile, which

Of note, the continuous formation of dendritic Li can even pierce through the separator, consequent to battery short-circuit and alarming safety hazards.8–10
Various endeavours have been devoted to addressing the above-mentioned issues related to Li metal anodes, which generally fall into two categories. One is the direct modication of the bulk structure of Li anodes via incorporating a threedimensional framework,11,12 synthesizing a dual phase Li alloy,13,14 and constructing Li metal composites.11,15 The interior scaffold can not only enhance the mechanical stability and retard the volume variation of the electrode, but can also act as the electrochemically active site to enlarge the surface area and regulate the Li deposition.11 The other way is to optimize the surface conditions of the Li metal anode to achieve a robust

Recently, constructing an articial SEI layer has attracted extensive attention, due to the advantageous simplicity in the preparation process and efficacy in suppressing dendrite growth. Typically, the protective lms are composed of inorganic insulators,21,22 inorganic ion conductors,23–26 Li alloys,27–30 polymers,31–33 or composites.19,47 Inorganic protective lms like Al2O3 (ref. 21) and Li3PO4 (ref. 24) with a high Young's modulus can effectively prevent the penetration of Li dendrites; however, the thin inorganic lms tend to become pulverized, due to the poor exibility and the rapidly accumulated internal stress, induced by the large volume evolution aer multiple Li stripping/depositing cycles. Alternatively, the polymer lm seems a good choice considering its high elasticity, lmforming properties and easy synthesis. Polymers like polyvinyl alcohol (PVA),33 hydroxypropyl methyl cellulose (HPMC),34 and b-phase polyvinylidene diuoride (b-PVDF)35 with large quantities of polar functional groups, enable strong interaction with Li ions (Li+), guiding uniform Li deposition. Wu and co-workers demonstrated a highly tight PVA layer on the Cu/Li surface to realize a dense deposition of Li without grain boundaries and voids, induced by the connement effect and lithiophilic feature of PVA coating.32 Similarly, Cao's group introduced a viscoelastic HPMC interlayer with excellent lithiophilicity and electrochemical and mechanical stability, enabling dendritefree and zero volume expansion Li anodes.34 Nevertheless, the relatively low ionic conductivity of most polymer lms limits the electrochemical performance of Li metal anodes, especially at high current density.36,37 In line with this, the inorganic species are oen incorporated into the polymer lms as llers. For instance, adding LiF particles to poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO),38 introducing Li bis-triuoromethyl sulfonate (LiTFSI) salt into polyethylene vinyl alcohol-b-acrylonitrile ether (EBC),20 and joining Cu3N nanoparticles to styrene butadiene rubber (SBR)39 have been reported as effective synergised interlayers for Li anodes. Despite this, the detachment of the articial protective layer during long cycles, resulting from the low binding ability between the coating lm and Li metal, is still a major challenge yet to be solved. Generally, polymer lms like polyacrylic acid (PAA),40 pentanoic acid,6 pendant PEO segments and ureidopyrimidinone (UPy)41 with strong binding ability, can in situ react with Li metal. One can expect that the combination of desired properties including high binding ability, strong Li+ homogenizing capability and superior ionic conductivity in the designed integrated protection layer could effectively resolve the issues of Li dendrite growth, volume change and side reactions.
Herein, we rationally design an articial hybrid protective layer composed of polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) and PAA via a one-step in situ reaction. PVA with sufficient hydroxyl groups can rmly bond with Li atoms to avoid the ion agglomeration around Li protrusions and achieve even Li deposition. Meanwhile, PVA is a widely used synthetic polymer with low-cost, and excellent thermal, mechanical, and chemical stabilities, coupled with good lm-forming properties.32,39,41 Unfortunately, the relatively low ionic
© 2023 The Author(s). Published by the Royal Society of Chemistry
conductivity and inferior binding ability with Li metal of PVA can retard the Li+ transportation under high current density and induce shortened lifespan of LMBs. Alternatively, PAA can in situ react with Li metal to form highly stretchable and favourable ionic conducting lithium polyacrylic acid (LiPAA) showing enhanced contact with Li metal and excellent stability, consequently adapting to volumetric change over multiple Li dissolution/ deposition processes.43–45 Accordingly, by mixing PVA and PAA as an articial protective layer, the advantages of uniform Li+ ux from PVA coupled with favourable Li+ conductivity and robust binding ability of LiPAA are synergized. Therefore, when such a hybrid polymer lm is applied in symmetric LijLi cells at various current densities, the cell exhibits enhanced cycling stability (700 h at 3 mA cm−2/1 mA h cm−2) in a carbonate ester-based electrolyte without any additive. While the PVA–PAA lm is coated on the Cu current collector, LijCu cells can smoothly cycle for 200 cycles under 3 mA cm−2/1 mA h cm−2 with a high coulombic efficiency (CE) of 97.5%. Our modied Li anode can readily resist the volume uctuation and prevent dendrite growth over long cycling. In addition, when paired with a high areal loading LiFePO4 cathode (about 2.45 mA h cm
−2), the LijLiFeO4 cell with a PVA–PAA coated Li anode displays a long lifespan of 180 cycles at 1.0 C, with a low-capacity decay percentage of 3.3%.

sections.heading: Preparation of PVA–PAA coated Cu foil
sections.text: PVA and PAA were mixed in different weight ratios (PVA : PAA = 1 : 0; 8 : 1; 4 : 1; 2 : 1; 1 : 1; 1 : 4; 0 : 1) and dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) under a concentration of 1 wt%. A uniform mixed solution was obtained aer vigorously stirring for 24 h. A glass rod was utilized to cast the solution on Cu foil. The coated Cu foil was then dried in an oven at 60 °C for 72 h to ensure the complete volatilization of DMSO solvent, and cut into a round disc of 19 mm diameter aer drying.

sections.heading: Preparation of PVA–PAA coated Li metal
sections.text: The coating process on Li foil was carried out in a glove box. Firstly, the native passivation lm on the Li metal surface was removed mechanically via scratching, and then the Li sheet was pressed into a disc with a diameter of 12 mm, and 20 mL of the mixed solution is added dropwise on the Li surface with a pipette, and dried naturally in a glove box. The thickness of the coating layer was controlled by adding dropwise different volumes on the Li foil.

sections.heading: Ionic conductivity measurements
sections.text:
A typical coin cell with stainless steel as the block electrode was assembled and tested in a frequency range from 100 kHz to 100 MHz with an amplitude of 10 mV. 20 mL of ester solution was applied as the electrolyte. The ionic conductivity can be obtained from the below equation:
s = L/RbS
where s (S cm−1) stands for the ionic conductivity, L (cm) represents the thickness of the polymer electrolyte, Rb (U) means the intrinsic impedance of the polymer electrolyte, and S (cm2) indicates the contact area between the stainless steel and polymer electrolyte.

sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text:
The fabrication process of the surface coating is displayed in Fig. 1a. The PVA–PAA layer on Li foil can be spontaneously produced by drop casting the PVA–PAA solution dissolved in DMSO with a mass fraction of 1 wt%, followed by natural evaporation in a glove box (Fig. 1a). With such a hybrid lm coated on the Li foil surface, Li+ ux can be effectively homogenized, leading to smooth deposition behaviours, whilst the dendrite gradually grows on bare Li foil (Fig. 1b). Fig. 2a and b show the optical and SEM images of Cu foils with and without PVA–PAA coating. The colour of the Cu foil turns brown and the surface becomes smoother aer casting PVA–PAA, as compared to bare Cu. The cross-sectional SEM image in Fig. 2c reveals that the thickness of the PVA–PAA protection layer on Cu foil is around 1.20 mm. Upon casting the PVA–PAA foil, the modied Li foil exhibits a glossier texture with a brighter colour and even surface (Fig. 2d and e). The thickness of the PVA–PAA protection layer on Li foil is also around 1.20 mm, as shown in Fig. 2f,

indicating that the reaction between metallic Li and PAA has no impact on the lm thickness.
The proportion of PVA and PAA as well as thickness of the coating layer are vital indices for the electrochemical performance of the PVA–PAA hybrid lm in ester electrolyte. Therefore, a series of PVA–PAA mixtures in various weight ratios (PVA : PAA = 1 : 0; 8 : 1; 4 : 1; 2 : 1; 1 : 4; 0 : 1) were dissolved in DMSO under a weight percentage of 1 wt%. From Fig. S1a,† Cu foil with only PVA coating can operate for 220 cycles with a CE of 98.0%. When a small amount of PAA is added to PVA (PAA : PVA = 1 : 8), the cycling behaviour was signicantly improved, due to the addition of PVA giving rising to LiPAA with relatively high ionic conductivity.42–44 The optimal electrochemical performance can be observed (CE: 98.5% aer 300 cycles at 1 mA cm−2, 1 mA h cm−2), when the weight ratio of PVA to PAA increases to 4 : 1. However, as the weight of PAA further increased, the length of the cycling period was lowered. Such a phenomenon indicates that the over-dose of PAA in PVA would deteriorate the lm integrity of the hybrid lm, thereby failing to isolate the electrolyte and

Hence, the weight ratio of 4 : 1 was selected as the optimal parameter, as both decent ionic conductivity and distributed Li+ ux can be synergized in the ultimate robust hybrid PVA–PAA lm. When increasing the current to 3 mA cm−2, the PVA–PAA layer with a weight ratio of 4 : 1 also exceled its counterparts (Fig. S1b†). Subsequently, Cu foil cast with PVA–PAA of different thickness was measured to investigate the appropriate coating thickness (PVA–PAA-1, PVA–PAA-2, PVA–PAA-3, and PVA–PAA-4). Clearly, the cycling lifespan of PVA–PAA-2@Cu foil was longer, as compared to its counterparts (Fig. S2†). The overthin layer tends to contain defects inside the structure, failing to isolate the electrolyte and resist the volume change over cycling. The over-thick coating layer may lead to insufcient structural integrity, and the consequent over-long transport path of ions could reduce the evenness of Li deposition.
Upon the optimization of preparation parameters, the CE of bare Cu foil, PVA, PAA and PAA–PVA (1 : 4) coated Cu foil was evaluated at a current density of 1 mA cm−2 and areal capacity of 1 mA h cm−2. Prior to the test, the ionic conductivity of different coating layers was evaluated with the precursor solution drop casting on stainless steel. 20 mL of ester solution was applied as the supporting electrolyte. As exhibited in Fig. S3,† the ionic conductivity of the ester electrolyte was higher (3.18 × 10−4 S cm−1), as compared to PAA (1.06 × 10−4 S cm−1), PVA (1.59 × 10−6 S cm−1) and PAA–PVA lms (5.03 × 10−5 S cm−1). The resistance in the high frequency range in Fig. S4† also followed the trend in Fig. S3† (PVA > PVA–PAA > PAA > liquid electrolyte). The thickness of the coating layer over the test is about 1.20 mm. Distinctly, the incorporation of PAA can improve the ionic conductivity of the PVA layer, favourable for the fast transport of Li+ and subsequent homogeneous growth. Additionally, the stress– strain proles of PVA and PVA–PAA lms are shown in Fig. S5.† As compared to the PVA lm, the coating layer of the PVA–PAA lm was markedly more stretchable (289% strain to its initial length), effectively adapting to the volume uctuation without brittle fracture.42,44
From Fig. 3a and b, the LijCu cell can only cycle for 120 and 40 cycles, respectively, at 1 mA cm−2/1 mA h cm−2 and 3 mA cm−2/1 mA h cm−2, as the non-uniform deposition of Li on pure Cu can induce the formation of dendrites and dead Li, thereby resulting in short cycle life and low CE. Aer coating the PVA lm with the function of uniform Li+ ux on the Cu foil, it can cycle stably for 220 and 90 cycles at 1 mA cm−2/ 1 mA h cm−2 and 3 mA cm−2/1 mA h cm−2, respectively. In stark contrast, the PVA–PAA casted Cu foil can smoothly operate for 300 (98.5%) and 200 (97.5%) cycles, respectively, under 1 mA cm−2/1 mA h cm−2 and 3 mA cm−2/1 mA h cm−2, demonstrating enhanced cycling stability as compared to the counterpart. Additionally, the CE of the as-prepared hybrid PVA–PAA was tested in ester electrolyte, as exhibited in Fig. S6,† where the CE of protected Cu foil clearly outperformed that of bare Cu foil. Such improvement can be attributed to the superior Li+ transmission and distribution capability of the hybrid PAA–PVA lm, enabling fast and

reversible Li redox reactions. The following voltage–capacity proles are disclosed in Fig. 3c and d. Although the initial capacity of both Cu and PAA–PVA@Cu was relatively low, PAA–PVA@Cu demonstrated the increased charge capacity and CE in the subsequent cycles. The inferior capacities of Cu foil and PAA–PVA@Cu in the 1st cycle were due to the generation of a SEI and LiPAA, respectively. In the remaining cycling, the occurrence of parasitic reactions and dead Li on bare Cu consumed a large amount of active Li, whilst PAA– PVA casted Cu foil can inhibit the side reactions and enable homogeneous Li nucleation. Furthermore, the relatively high charge capacity and low polarisation voltage of the cell with PAA–PVA coated Cu foil aer 200 cycles, in compared to Cu, suggest a stabilised interface induced by the hybrid polymer coating.

From the cross-sectional view in Fig. 4c and S7,† the thickness of Li deposition on bare Cu was about 64 mm, much larger than the theoretical thickness (25 mm), suggestive of a loose structure of deposited Li. In contrast, the deposited Li on the PVA–PAA coated Cu foil shows a at coating surface with dense Li growth below (the thickness is 25 mm, Fig. 4d–f). This indicates that Li+ can transport though the PVA–PAA polymer layer and distribute homogeneously to achieve uniform nucleation and dissolution behaviours, thereby suppressing dendrite growth and buffering dimensional variation. Furthermore, the deposited Li was electrochemically extracted from the coated Cu electrode under the same conditions. From the SEM image in Fig. S8,† the coating layer on Cu foil returned to the original state, and becomes smoother and atter aer the Li extraction, due to the reaction between PAA and Li. This indicates that such a mechanically robust lm can induce uniform deposition of Li and resist the volume change in the subsequent cycling process.
The application of the hybrid PAA–PVA polymer layer directly on Li metal was also investigated via a symmetric cell conguration. Similarly, the coating layer thickness on Li foil was assessed upon adjusting the drop volume of precursor solution to explore the optimal parameter. Under a current density of 3 mA cm−2 with a xed capacity of 1 mA h cm−2 in carbonate-based electrolyte, the symmetric cell of PVA–PAA30 on Li foil maintained a longer cycling period and smaller polarization hysteresis, in comparison to the reference cells (Fig. S9†). Hence, a dose of 30 mL was chosen as the optimal condition for modifying the surface of Li foil, with a thickness of 1.2 mm, equalling the optimal thickness of the coating on Cu foil. An equivalent circuit (Fig. S10a† inset) was used to t these impedance spectra using ZView soware. The RS, Rf, and RCT respectively stand for the bulk resistance of the cell, surface passivation layer, and charge-transfer process.46,47 The tting results of overall resistance are displayed in Table S1.† The initial impedance of the LijLi symmetric cell was 415.2 U. Aer 50 cycles, the impedance reduces to 175.1 U, due to the activation process, and then gradually increases in the subsequent cycles (100th cycle: 190.0 U; 200th cycle: 253.7 U). The underneath reasons lie in the brittle original SEI continuing to crack and grow during the cycle, resulting in non-uniform current distribution and high Li+ ux near cracks. The growth of dendrite Li and accumulation of dead Li exhibit high impedance, as shown in the Nyquist plot. Despite markedly large initial impedance of the PVA–PAA coated LijLi symmetric cell (762.4 U) in the 1st cycle, as compared to the LijLi cell, due to relatively low conductivity of the coating layer in contrast to liquid electrolyte, the modied cell maintained a stable small impedance in the following circulation (95.1, 88.1 and 93.2 U in the 50th, 100th and 200th cycles, respectively). The steadied trend of resistance of the modied Li cell can directly suggest the successfully in-built robust lm on the anode surface, which can distribute Li+ ux rapidly and homogeneously to resist the dimensional expansion and dendritic growth. As shown in Fig. 5a and b and S11,† the
5098 | Nanoscale Adv., 2023, 5, 5094–5101
voltage hysteresis of the pure LijLi symmetric cell increased signicantly when cycling to 120 h, and a short circuit occurred at 260 h. In contrast, the coated Li‖Li cell shows boosted long-cycle performance of stable operation for 700 and 250 h under 1 mA cm−2/1 mA h cm−2 and 3 mA cm−2/ 1 mA h cm−2, respectively. Additionally, the largest polarization hysteresis of the symmetric cell with PVA coating validates the inadequate ionic conductivity of PVA, unable to rapidly transport Li+, particularly under high current density. The cycling behaviours were consistent with electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) data in Fig. S10 and Table S1.† There are three possible causes for such observation: (i) the ne coating layer can provide a stable interface in between the Li surface and electrolyte, to regulate the Li+ ux and prevent side reactions; (ii) the favourable ionic conductivity of the hybrid lm can ensure the rapid transmission of Li+, instead of local accumulation; (iii) the PVA–PAA layer with a high binding ability between the coating layer and Li metal, coupled with considerable mechanical strength and exibility, can guarantee the tight contact of the polymer lm and anode, and well adapt to volume changes during long cycles. Those synergistic effects can enable rational Li nucleation/ dissolution behaviour and consequently long lifespan.
The outstanding performances of PVA–PAA coated Li in symmetric cells demonstrate its high feasibility in practical cells. Herein, a commercial LiFeO4 cathode with an areal capacity of 2.45 mA h cm−2 was adopted to pair with the PVA– PAA coated Li anode. As shown in Fig. 5c, the PVA–PAA coated LijLFP cell delivered a high reversible capacity of 148.2 mA h g−1 at 1.0 C (1.92 mA cm−2) and maintained a discharge capacity of 124.8 mA h g−1 aer 180 cycles, with a retention rate of 96.7%. LijLFP cell decays from 148.8 to 74.4 mA h g−1 aer 65 cycles at 1.0 C. The Galvanostatic charge/discharge curves in Fig. S12† showed the polarization voltage of the LijLFP cell markedly increased aer multiple cycles, probably due to the accumulation of dead Li impeding the transfer of Li at the interfaces, and resulting in low CE and fast capacity decay. The rate performances of the full cells were measured at different current densities (Fig. 5d). The modied LijLFP cell delivered a higher specic capacity of 147.8, 143.1, 135.8, 130.4, and 121.2 mA h g−1 respectively at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1.0 and 2.0 C, in comparison to the LijLFP cell (145.2, 142.5, 138.5, 125.2, and 111.3 mA h g−1 at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1.0 and 2.0 C, respectively). The increased capacity difference of the two cells along with the rise of applied current suggests the generation of dendrites and dead Li on unmodied Li can aggravate the uneven deposition of Li, particularly at a high rate.
To further illustrate the role of the PVA–PAA protective layer, post-mortem SEM images were collected to study the morphology of the Li metal anode aer 50 cycles at a current density of 1 mA cm−2 with a xed capacity of 1 mA h cm−2. From Fig. 6a–c, vast quantities of dendrites and dead Li were formed on the uncoated Li metal anode, caused by uneven Li deposition and serious side-reactions between Li metal and electrolyte. In contrast, the surface of modied Li anode revealed a at and dense texture, with the PVA–PAA lm tightly coating on the top, effectively isolating the electrolyte and offering a stabilized interface (Fig. 6d–f).
The structural evolutions of bare Li and PVA–PAA coated Li are displayed in Fig. 7 to demonstrate the protection mechanism of the functional polymer layer. Owing to the nature of high reactivity and ultralow reduction potential, Li metal tends to interact with the electrolyte to form an SEI layer in the initial cycle. During Li plating, the uneven distribution of Li+ ux and the rough electrode surface can cause nonuniform Li deposition and dendrite growth. The accompanying large dimensional uctuation would rupture the fragile SEI and expose fresh Li, which can further react with the electrolyte to form a new SEI. Such a process of continuous cracking and repair of the SEI would repeat in the subsequent
© 2023 The Author(s). Published by the Royal Society of Chemistry
cycles, over-consuming active Li and electrolyte, corroding the anode surface, and producing enormous dead Li. In the end, the Li anode will become porous or even pulverized. In stark contrast, when PVA–PAA was applied as an articial SEI on the top of Li surface, the above-mentioned challenges could be addressed. The superior Li+ distribution capability, the decent mechanical strength and good lm-forming properties of PVA as well as good ionic conductivity and tight contact with Li metal of PAA were rationally incorporated in the hybrid lm. Hence, the PVA–PAA layer can enable strong binding with the Li anode, homogeneous Li+ ux and a rapid Li+ transportation rate, achieving uniform and compact deposition of Li without dendrite formation and volume uctuation.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, we have successfully demonstrated that the asprepared PVA–PAA hybrid coating layer can effectively stabilize the electrode/electrolyte interface and inhibit the growth of Li dendrites. Therefore, a large deposition of Li (5 mA h cm−2) on coated Cu foil can obtain a uniform and dense electrode. The LijCu half cells can stably cycle for 300 cycles at 1 mA cm−2/1 mA h cm−2, with a high CE of 98.5%. The symmetric cell with PVA–PAA coating can continuously operate for 250 h at a high current of 3 mA cm−2 under an areal capacity of 1 mA h cm−2. In addition, when applied to commercial LFP cathodes, the PVA–PAA@LijLFP cell displayed excellent rate and cycling performances (180 cycles at 1.0 C with a capacity retention of 96.66%; 121.2 mA h g−1 at 2.0 C). The reasons behind the phenomena are as follows: (1) the PVA–PAA coating layer can isolate the electrolyte and reactive Li metal to prevent side-reactions and over-consumption of active materials; (2) the PVA–PAA coating layer can induce uniform Li+ ow and promote Li+ transmission, ensuring uniform Li nucleation/dissolution; (3) the PVA–PAA coating layer possesses high binding ability to closely combine with Li and alleviate the dimensional variation over multiple cycles. Consequently, a dense Li anode with dendrite-free morphology can be achieved even aer long-term cycling. In short, using such a multifunctional articial protective layer can be a promising strategy to address the non-uniform deposition and dendrite growth in the anode of practical LMBs.
